text: (metal clinks)
(eggshell cracks)
(oil sizzles)
(upbeat music)
- Hello, and welcome to Sorted Food.

Today, two of our normal
home cooks, Jamie and Barry,

will be blind taste-testing
identical dishes,

and we're gonna ask them,
can they pick the premium?
By doing this with a bit of luck,

we will all learn better
where to spend our money,

how much difference there
actually is in these ingredients
and which of our normal home cooks
has the most talented tongue.
- Ah, what?

- I don't want to know who
has the most skilled tongue.

- Get your bets in at
home, it's round one.
(swanky music)

Okay, simple rules, you got
A and B in front of you.

Start with A, have a touch,
have a smell, have a nibble.
- Oh, it's a sandwich.
- Is it focaccia?
- Is it focaccia?
- Very good, Jamie.

You have two portions
of sea salt focaccia.

We've kept it really
simple, olive oil, sea salt,
and all the ingredients for focaccia,

but they are identical in
the way they've been made,

the way the ingredients
have been weighed out,
the proving times, the baking times.

The only thing that is different
is one of the ingredients
is more premium in one of those plates.
- Straight away, B is lighter.
It's as if I can feel more air pockets
and crispier on the outside.
Mm-hmm!
And, it has more of a chew.

They are both outrageously
delicious, that's for sure.

- Which is the ingredient do
you think we're comparing?
There's not many ingredients in focaccia.
- You wouldn't compare yeast, would we?
Flour!

- Yeah, so we kind of
wanted to explore flour

because I think we all think
of it as such a basic staple.

What happens if you buy
a particularly cheap one
versus one that you spend a bit more on?
Is it worth spending the money?
- I look for the type of flour,

you know, strong flour,
self-raising flour,

whatever it is that I
need for the application,

but not, I wouldn't
necessarily go for a brand.
- I've bought premium flour at home

when making my own pizza doughs
and it changes everything.
Suddenly it puffs up completely different.

- So both of these are
strong white bread flour.

One is a supermarket basic
and one is more premium.
Can you pick the premium?

- I feel like A has a
more luxurious bite to it.
I'm gonna say A is the premium.
- I believe that B is the premium.

- In that case, you've
locked in your answer.
You have said that B is the premium.
Now take off the blindfold

and see if there are
any visual differences

and whether you would, not
that you can, change your mind.
- Looking at them doesn't really help.

- But B has more height,
it has risen more.

- I can reveal to you that in
this first round, the premium
is B.
(bell chimes)
(buzzer honks)
A is ASDA's own strong white bread flour.

B is Shipton Mill artisanal
Canadian wheat flour.

And what Shipton do, is
kind of small batch milling,
but also they combine different wheats

from different places,
local farms in the UK,
but also from farmers around the world
they have good supply chains with,
and they constantly blend the flour.
So it's consistent

and you always know exactly
how it's gonna perform.
- That's really interesting.

Is there anything I should've
been looking out for?
- The bubbles is an interesting one

because they had identical
proving times, everything else.

And what happened with
the slightly cheaper flour
was that they formed the bubbles

and then basically they didn't
have the structure to hold it
and therefore they collapse.
So what you ended up with was crispy bits

where a bubble had popped
and it goes crispier
but the structure wasn't the same.
- Interesting.

- The ASDA flour works
out at 40 pence per kilo.
(cha chings)

How much do you recon
for the Shipton Mill?
- 60p a kilo?
50% more?

- I wouldn't be surprised
if it's like three pounds.
- One pound 55 a kilo.

- You kinda led me down
that path (chuckles).
- You're still only looking at 70 or 80p

to make a loaf of focaccia,
but it is four times the price.
- Price-wise, that is fine by me.
- But if it is easier to work with

and you are supporting a
smaller, more local business,
that's a good thing.
- You scored a point, on to round two.
- Yeah!
- Rumbags.
(upbeat music)
That was warm-up round Ebbers,
so let's make this serious now.
- Round number two.
- I'm smelling a curry.
- Hmm!
Is this a chicken biryani of sorts?
- Excellent guess, chicken biryani.

The question is, what is
the premium ingredient
we want you to try and identify?
- Rice.
- It's the rice we're looking at here.
- Both have been made with basmati rice.
- [Barry] Okay, oh, wait a minute.
- Literally the only place in the planet
where it's acceptable to do this.

- A are longer grains of rice
that are slightly silkier.

B is shorter and probably
plumper and fluffier.

- I feel like I'm getting
more flavor from A.
- One is a supermarket own brand,
and one is what we consider
to be one of the more premium,
a rice brand that we know

that Michelin star Indian
restaurants in London do use.
- So A is the premium.
- A is your answer, it's locked in.

You may now reveal the
blindfolds, have a little look.

- On visual inspection, I
think I'm happy with my answer.
I think A has longer, less broken grains.

- [Barry] B looks like
the rice I use at home,
and that is not premium.
- I can reveal that in this round,
the premium product
is A.

- Yes!
- Yes!

(bell chimes)
- Absolutely right.
And it is slightly longer grains,
slightly more fluffy and individual.

You're right in the sense
they I haven't broken as much,
and much more fragrant and floral.
Basmati literally means aroma engrained.
- It is far more aromatic than B is.

I mean, it's not to say
that both aren't delicious
because they really, really are.

- A is Veetee Mega, extra
long grain aged basmati,
B is Liddell's basmati rice.
- [Barry] Sorry, aged basmati?

- So if you look at the
color of it as well,
it's a slightly off-white.

Our understanding is
it's aged in the sacks
and the flavor just has the chance
to kind of integrate more.

I genuinely don't know a
huge amount about that.
If you do, comment down below.
What decisions did you go through
when you come to buying it?
- I don't really make a decision.

I just go for a normal
supermarket own brand.

- Which I think is definitely
a factor of the trust
that we outsource to retailers.

There are occasions when
perhaps if you go off-piste,
you might end up with a better result.

- This doesn't really
the smell of anything.
Whereas this smells of everything.
- What I found fascinating

was the aroma compound
you're kinda smelling
is the same one that you find in pandan.

So that very aromatic,
floral, almost grassy note

and basmati rice has 12
times as much of that
as non-basmati grains.

So you did get that one right,
but now, let's talk price.

We picked this up from Liddell
and per kilo, one pound 29.

Perfectly good basmati
rice, creates a great dish.

How much for the Veetee
Mega, extra long grain?
- Four pounds per kilo.

- Can't be that much more
premium, so I'd say two pounds.
- You're going with two pounds a kilo?
- Two pounds 20.
- Should've stuck to two pounds, bang on!
So it's about 50% more,

but that's only 70 odd
pence more per kilo.
- But now I know that's the difference,

maybe I should care more
about the rice I buy.
- Yeah, I would definitely choose that.

I think over the course
of however many meals
you would get out of a packet of rice,
that cost will be negligible,
but the difference in quality is massive.

- [Benjamin] Stop eating
that so we can try some.
- Ah, what a day.
- On to round three!
(upbeat music)

- So far, humble ingredients,
spectacular outcomes.
Oh, okay, it's wet.
(laughs)
- What is that?
- Oh, okay, it's an omelet.
Ooh, good omelet!
(sniffs)
- Egg.
- Correct.
- Right, there was nothing in the omelet.
So I'm gonna say, we're looking at eggs.
- We are looking at eggs.

In front of you, you have
two classic French omelets.

One of those plates is made
with regular free range eggs,

and one is made with a more
premium free range egg.
- Texture's pretty similar.

- I think everyone at home
probably already has an idea
based on visuals.

Obviously, Jamie doesn't
have those visuals.

- I cook a lot of eggs at
home and eggs is of the things
that I do spend quite a lot of money on.
When I have used cheaper eggs,

it does feel like they've
been watered down a little bit
and A tastes like the eggs I make at home.
So I'm gonna say A is the premium.
- Ah, I really don't know!
A.
- A is locked in, that is your premium.

Now take off your blindfold
and see what we can see.
- This one's luminous!
- Are they Burford Browns?
- Yeah, the color does kinda give it away,
A is the premium.
- Yes, okay!

(bell chimes)
- So A is a free range egg,
a Burford Brown from Clarence Court.

And B, also free range,
from Sainsbury's J. James.
- [Barry] That was really tricky.
- Start with the Sainbury's ones.

It's got a QR code on the
inside for full traceability
and providence and each egg has a code.
If you put the code into the egg tracker,

they have come from Shirley
Blackwood in Scotland.
So everything is completely transparent.
- [Jamie] That's really good to know.
- A 100% of people want to know more
about where their food comes from.
In the example of Clarence Court,

it's come from Clarence Court
and you go to the website

and they've got videos,
you can see the hens.

It is incredibly transparent
and premium as a result.
- What a beautiful color.
- The hens enjoy a maize-rich diet,

carefully formulated to
include wheat, sunflower,

seashell, soya, paprika, and
marigold from dawn till dusk.

- A couple in there that
surprise me, if I'm honest.
Seashells, they're eating seashells?
- Help with calcium I guess.

- And paprika, adds a
little bit of a kick?
- Color?

- They're some pretentious
eggs (chuckles).

- Tell me Ben, where did
the marigold come from?
- Their flowerbeds.
- Right. (beeps)

- If we are baking, I will
buy, and I need a lot of them.

I'll go for a slightly cheaper
range, but not much cheaper.

- And I guess one thing
that we're quite lucky with
in the UK, is the farming standards.
The Clarence Court Burford Browns,
they have free roam all day, rich diet.
But even the J.James Sainsbury's ones,
they are also free range,
they still have access to the outside.

They still have perch space
because that is legislation

that under EU law we've
always had to abide by,

which is why we have excellent
food standards in the UK.

- I think I would still
spend more money on the eggs.

I wouldn't necessarily
go for the cheaper option
because it's not gonna taste as good.

There's a lot more going
on than just the taste.

- 15 pence an egg from
J.James Sainsbury's.
How much do you recon for Clarence Court?
- 20p an egg.
- 50 pence an egg.
- [Jamie] Quite a lot more, aint it?

- [Benjamin] So just over
three times the price

per egg.
- Quite a bit more.

- If the egg is the star of
the show, spend the money.

- Going into the final
round, J, you got two points,
chance to pick up a third.
(upbeat music)
Oh, you're in such a lucky seat, J.

Last round, number four,
same rules apply, off you go!
- Oh!
It's a pie.
- [Benjamin] Go easy on that mouthful.
- Oh, alright.
- [Barry] Mushroom pie?
- [Benjamin] You have two mushroom pies.

What's the premium
ingredient we're looking for?
The filling or the casing?
- [Barry] Mmm.
- One of those was made with a punnet
of supermarket Chestnut mushrooms,

and one was made with a
more premium selection.
- A, is a wetter mix.
- B feels drier and more coarse.

- And also, I'd say it's
more mushroom-y in flavor.
So I'm gonna go with B being the premium.
- B is the premium.
- B is you're locked in answer.
Blindfolds off.
- [Barry] Yeah.

- [Benjamin] Any big
differences on preference?
- You know what?
I'm surprised at how similar they are.

- Supermarkets obviously have
a range of mushrooms available
all year round,

but right now is when you'll
probably find more variety
when it comes to wild mushrooms.
- The filling in B,

the mushrooms definitely
look more interesting.

- Not that we were allowing
you to change your mind,
but it sounds like you wouldn't.
- Don't think so.
- And you shouldn't.
B is the premium.
- Well, hey!
- [Benjamin] Three out of four.
- Three out of four.
- Good, yeah, yeah!

- A is a punnet of supermarket
Chestnut mushrooms.
B is a punnet of mixed wild mushrooms.
They're sold as a wild, mixed selection.

And therefore you kind
of get what arrives.

So there, a mixture of
chanterelle, girolles,
black trumpet mushrooms.
So let's talk price.

I'm gonna do it per kilo
to keep things easy.
You don't often buy a kilo of mushrooms,
but A, three pounds 15 per kilo.
- To that level, you look at it like,
stuff it, I reckon 20 quid.
- Five pounds per kilo?
- 35 pounds a kilo.
So more than 10 times the price.
- Whoa!
That's an astonishing price difference.

- If you're just looking
for a mushroom sensation,
then go with these every day of the week
and save those for maybe once a month.

- We were deliberately trying
to test your taste buds today.

I would not recommend you
spend 35 pounds per kilo

if you're going to blitz them
up and put them in a pie.

But some applications, they
absolutely have a place,
especially at this time of year
when they're very, very seasonal.
But what are your thoughts?
- I'll be honest with you, Ebbers,

I'm not gonna change my
day-to-day mushroom habits.

I'm gonna carry on buying
supermarket mushrooms.

But I will keep an eye out
for a punnet of something
that looks a little bit different.

I'm never going to buy a
kilo of mushrooms at a time,
so the 35 pound price tag feels obtrusive.
- And that's bang on.
So I can now reveal.
- Yes.

- Barry, you know you
got four out of four,
100%, that is excellent.

- J, believe it or not,
Barry beat you again.
- Number one, he never beats me.
Number two, how did he get four correct?
- Very talented tongue.

- That's not what I was
after, but thank you.
- Genuinely, I love doing these
'cause it's not often you get to do

what we consider to be staple
ingredients side by side,
to look at the comparisons.

Tell us though, where would
you spend the extra pence

or pounds if you were to do it
out of those four ingredients
and comment down below,

what should we pick the
premium on next time.

- [Jamie] We have an app,
it's called Meal Packs

and helps you plan and then
cook a week's worth of meals
using one set of ingredients,

saving you money, cutting
down on food waste
and answering the age old question,
what should we have for dinner.
It's free to try for a whole month.
